The capital city is Matsuyama.Nussbaum, "Matsuyama" at p. 621. ==History== Until the Meiji Restoration, Ehime prefecture was known as Iyo Province.Nussbaum, "Provinces and prefectures" at p. 780. The name Ehime comes from the Kojiki. It means "beautiful maiden." After the Battle of Sekigahara, the Tokugawa shogun gave the area to his allies. Kato Yoshiaki built Matsuyama Castle which became the center of the modern city of Matsuyama. Drought is common in Ehime history.Berga, L. (2006). Dams and Reservoirs, Societies and Environment in the 21st Century, Vol. 1, p. 41. ==Geography== Ehime faces the Seto Inland Sea in the southwestern part of Shikoku. The prefecture is bordered by Kagawa Prefecture and Tokushima Prefecture in the east. Kōchi is to the south. The prefecture has a long coastline and it includes many islands.
